form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Alexander (for himself, Mr. Coons, Ms. Murkowski, Ms. Cantwell, Mr. Gardner, Mrs. Feinstein, and Mr. Heinrich) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources

form.official-title: To extend, improve, and consolidate energy research and development programs, and for other purposes.

subsection.text: This Act may be cited as the Energy Title of America COMPETES Reauthorization Act of 2015.
The table of contents of this Act is as follows:

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.
TITLE I—Energy title of America COMPETES programs
TITLE II—Elimination and consolidation of programs
Sec. 203. Consolidation of duplicative program authorities.

section.text: Section 5012 of the America COMPETES Act (42 U.S.C. 16538) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (a)(3), by striking subsection (n)(1) and inserting subsection (o)(1);
in subsection (i), by striking paragraph (1) and inserting the following:
To the maximum extent practicable, the Director shall ensure that—

subparagraph.text: the activities of ARPA–E are coordinated with, and do not duplicate the efforts of, programs and laboratories within the Department and other relevant research agencies; and

ARPA–E does not provide funding for a project unless the prospective grantee demonstrates sufficient attempts to secure private financing or indicates that the project is not independently commercially viable.

paragraph.text: by redesignating subsection (n) as subsection (o);
by inserting after subsection (m) the following:

subsection.text: The following types of information collected by the ARPA–E from recipients of financial assistance awards shall be considered privileged and confidential and not subject to disclosure under section 552 of title 5, United States Code:

paragraph.text: Plans for commercialization of technologies developed under the award, including business plans, technology-to-market plans, market studies, and cost and performance models.

Investments provided to an awardee from third parties (such as venture capital firms, hedge funds, and private equity firms), including amounts and the percentage of ownership of the awardee provided in return for the investments.
Additional financial support that the awardee—

subparagraph.text: plans to or has invested into the technology developed under the award; or
is seeking from third parties.

paragraph.text: Revenue from the licensing or sale of new products or services resulting from research conducted under the award.

subsection.header: University nuclear science and engineering support
subsection.text: Section 954 of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 (42 U.S.C. 16274) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (a), by inserting nuclear chemistry, after nuclear engineering,; and
in subsection (b)—

subparagraph.text: by redesignating paragraphs (3) through (5) as paragraphs (4) through (6), respectively; and
by inserting after paragraph (2) the following:

paragraph.text: award grants, not to exceed 5 years in duration, to institutions of higher education with existing academic degree programs in nuclear sciences and related fields—

subparagraph.text: to increase the number of graduates in nuclear science and related fields;
to enhance the teaching and research of advanced nuclear technologies;
to undertake collaboration with industry and National Laboratories; and
to bolster or sustain nuclear infrastructure and research facilities of institutions of higher education, such as research and training reactors and laboratories;

subsection.header: Consolidation of Department of Energy early career awards for science, engineering, and mathematics researchers program and distinguished scientist program

paragraph.text: Section 971(c) of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 (42 U.S.C. 16311(c)) is amended by adding at the end the following:

For the Department of Energy early career awards for science, engineering, and mathematics researchers program under section 5006 of the America COMPETES Act (42 U.S.C. 16534) and the distinguished scientist program under section 5011 of that Act (42 U.S.C. 16537), $150,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2016 through 2020, of which not more than 65 percent of the amount made available for a fiscal year under this paragraph may be used to carry out section 5006 or 5011 of that Act.
